awd_abstract_narration:
The goal of this project is to study the mechanics of colloidal membranes---membranes comprised of colloidal particles such as filamentous viruses or DNA origami bundles. These membranes have life-like abilities reminiscent of cell membranes, such as the ability to heal themselves or assemble spontaneously into complex and controllable shapes. Many of the technological advances of the twentieth century were made possible by discoveries in materials engineering. The development of corrosion-resistant stainless steel, synthetic polymers such as nylon, semiconductors and integrated circuits, and liquid crystals used in displays have all had a profound impact on society and our quality of life. Each of these advances required the theoretical framework and experimental techniques necessary to understand and control the material properties of inanimate matter. Today we are at the beginning of a new era of bio-inspired materials engineering, as it is now just becoming possible to create and control materials consisting of biological components and with the distinctive properties of living matter. The PIs will develop the theoretical and computational tools to predict and control the mechanics of colloidal membranes and how colloidal membrane shape depends on the experimental conditions. The research approach has the potential to bridge the physics, math and engineering communities. Educational YouTube videos related to the research will also be created for outreach to the public.

Colloidal membranes are promising for their potential as highly reconfigurable microscopic structures, and as analogs to biological materials such as lipid bilayer membranes. While colloidal membranes share many properties with lipid bilayer membranes, such as their fluidity, they also have their own unique aspects, including a low energy cost for having edges. The study of the mechanics of these objects is still in its infancy, and requires a multidisciplinary approach including elements from solid mechanics, statistical mechanics, liquid crystal physics, and differential geometry. The research team will carry out three specific tasks: (i) calculate the entropy-driven or chirality-driven instability and subsequent nonlinear evolution of flat disk-shaped membranes to rippled helical sheets and twisted ribbons, (ii) calculate the force vs. extension relation for membrane disks and helicoidal ribbons, and (iii) predict and classify the shapes of colloidal membranes of more complex topology, such as catenoids and other observed structures with multiple holes.

por.por_cntn:
This project is a theoretical and computational study of the shapes of colloidal membranes. The motivation is to develop new materials with life-like properties, such as the ability to heal or change shape. Colloidal membranes are constructed artificially using rod-shaped viruses which are about one micron long and about ten nanometers in diameter. These viruses are the colloidal particles. When the colloidal particles are suspended in water with small polymer particles at the right concentration, the osmotic forces of the polymer particles crowd the rods together to form a membrane in which the rods are mostly parallel to each other and form one layer (see the figure). Like cellular membranes, colloidal membranes have a resistance to bending like a solid plate, but also have the ability to flow like a thin film of fluid. The fluidity of colloidal membranes makes them highly reconfigurable. A solid piece of paper cannot be wrapped around an orange without tearing or forming creases, but a flat colloidal membrane can bend into a sphere smoothly because the rods can flow within the membrane like a liquid. A second important aspect of colloidal membranes is that the viruses have a desire to twist with a certain handedness when packed together. In a planar layer, the rods cannot twist, and are therefore frustrated. However, colloidal membranes typically have free edges (instead of closing up like a cell membrane), and near the edge the rods can twist.

The intellectual merit of this project is that it provides the theoretical framework for the design and control of the shape of colloidal membranes. First, we showed that the tendency of colloidal membranes to form saddle-like shapes arises from the entropy of the polymers in solution. It turns out that the volume that is accessible to the polymers is greater when the membrane has a saddle-like curvature then when it curved like the cap of a sphere. Since greater accessible volume for the polymers means they have greater entropy, saddle-like shapes are favored. Second, we developed a new theory to determine the membrane shape without keeping track of the configuration of all of the rods in the membrane. Instead, the effect of the twist of the rods at the edge on the membrane shape is captured by adding parameters to the theory that control the edge length, curvature, and a property that measures the twist of the edge known as the geodesic torsion. Using this effective theory we successively predicted the experimentally measured fluctuations of the membrane edge. These fluctuations are driven by the random thermal motion (Brownian motion) of the molecules in the water. Our theory also allowed us to determine some of the values of the parameters of the theory. Third, we showed that a membrane disk subject to stretching twists into a helical shape. This response is remarkable since usually helical objects unwind when subject to stretching. Finally, we developed new computer simulation techniques to determine the nonuniform shapes of colloidal membranes.

The broader impacts of this work have been the training of several undergraduate, masters, and doctoral students. The students came from a variety of departments: applied mathematics, mechanical engineering, and physics, reflecting the interdisciplinary nature of the work. The PI participated in the Leadership Alliance Early Identification Summer Research Program and mentored a student working on research in this project. Students in two of the PIs graduate courses also made YouTube videos introducing soft matter concepts to a general audience.
